content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								Review based on V1.01Most of what is good in this game has to do with the fact that for the most part its gameplay is copied directly from the original (1994) XCOM. XCOM is easily one of the best designed games ever, so a faithful remake can't be too bad by definition, and this one is not bad at all.Where Xenonauts tries to diverge from XCOM it does that with mixed results. For example, the alien races are quite a bit more diverse. One of the starting races is tough, has innate regeneration, but poor eyesight and is best dealt with from a distance. The starting weapons are great - the classic pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper rifle and machine gun differ not only in stats (as in the original), but in their tactical values. Shotguns are deadly close-up, machines guns dish out tons of damage and can easily punch through obstacles, sniper rifles are amazingly accurate from a distance. Advancing the weapon tech is, unfortunately, quite boring. It is the same set of classic weapon archetypes all over again, only gradually more powerful. This is exactly the same as in the original game, but after seeing the initial diversity of ballistic weapons this was very disappointing. I had the same issue with the Firaxis XCOM - a "laser shotgun" just has to be one of the silliest sci-fi weapon concepts. The more interesting parts of the original tech tree, like the mind probe, the motion scanner, the psi technology and the blaster launcher are no longer in the game. The UFO activity seems to be much more involved, later in the game the aliens will start defending their missions with aggressive fighter wings that will bring down your dropship or fighters returning from a mission if you are not careful. The aerial terror missions are also a nice touch.On the other hand, the interception mini-game is highly repetitive, and very slow-paced - I have been using autoresolve most of the time because it gets very tedious after just a few interceptions, and the game will usually swarm you with UFOs because of how the economy works.I really didn't like the change where the engineers can no longer build items for profit - that option made a lot of sense in the original game (though was  probably too good to the point of Xenonauts' authors calling the feature an "exploit"). In Xenonauts your engineers are just wasted resources unless you need something built immediately, which you don't always do, so they have to be fired / re-hired as needed to save money.The funding provided by the nations is just about enough to run 2 bases and fund two workshops. The only source of income for further expansion are the UFO raids, which are (relatively) less profitable than in the original, and therefore have to be more frequent. There is even an option to earn about 33% of the downed UFO's worth by bombing the crash site in order to avoid losing money when the ground squad is not available. Still, the income is quite low. For instance, the cost of a new base is $1M. Medium-sized UFOs that are prevalent in the mid game are worth about $50-75K if you raid them and $25K if you bomb them, minus the combat losses that can be VERY painful (a basic scout vehicle costs $60K to produce, and they are easy to lose). This means that in order to get a new base you need to raid about 15 UFOs with near perfect performance, and that is not considering the cost of buildings, staff and maintenance.Ground combat is pretty much the same as in the original game, except for the cover system that can sometimes be frustrating because it is not at all obvious how it calculates the lines of fire, and the game won't show you the cover calculations unless you are aiming at something.The game's performance is frankly embarrassing at times. The Geoscape scrolling is very laggy, visibility calculations cause obvious frame rate drops on larger maps, and the animations seem not to load until they are played for the first time, so the first time a new animation is shown it is basically dropped frames. This is simply unacceptable for a 2D game that is not particularly more complex than a 20 year old game that ran fine on computers compared to which your today's phone is a freaking alien planetary mainframe.Overall, the game does not really add that much to the original XCOM experience, however it recreates it quite successfully. I am finding myself returning to play just a couple more missions all the time.

content:
11
												Bought this game a while ago and thought it was time to write a review.If you love the old UFO/XCOM games (the MSDOS ones from Microsoft) you will love this game. It is VERY similar comapred to those classics, with of course imrpoved graphics and gameplay.Everything you loved in the old games is here..and more....or better,sometimes both.The intercepting of an ufo for example. Now you can control andgive directions to your fighters,where to fly,to evade,afterburner etc. Its possible to shoot down a large UFO, by using inferiour/outdated crafts and weapons, by just apllying a good strategy. Some UFOS have escort crafts, some ufos need rockets(torpedos) to make them land. There are alot of options.The actual isometric ground combat is much harder than in the old Xcoms. The aliens are more deadly and smarter than the Mircoprose ones. It requires care and patience to surivive the first missions without casualties. In general, the learning curve for thsi game is steeper in every aspect. The financial part is very challening. To keep your bases running and build new fighters and weapons or armor is costly. Even the base locations took me several starts to really get a cost efficient coverage of the globe. Of course all the other game aspects from the classics are here. Base construction, research, building items, improving your squad etc are all here...but as i mentiond just better polished.I played the early 2000 UFO games,which were realtime and hated them. I played the 2k Xcom and never really liked it. It looks flashy, but the gameplay is just boring and stale. It does not feel grand and very limited.Xenonauts gives me all the freedom i want ...and it makes me pay for it, if i make poor decisions....but i love it.

								Xenonauts is Xcom's less flashy, more in-depth brother: where Xcom is streamlined and sexy, Xenonauts is more tactical and strategic. In other words, where Xcom is more about how a team of super heroes saves the world by working their way up to god-like power and ability, Xenonauts is more like a real special forces sim: sooner or later, something is going to get someone (or half the team) whacked, and your going need to prepare if you don't want to lose the game. In other words, the loss hurts, but it is far more manageble than Xcom.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Xenonauts is a wonderful clone of the original XCOM - UFO DEFENSE and is in many ways a better experience. Xenonauts is more intuitive and pretty than its predecesor as well as creating the same feeling that you are juggling 9001 balls at once, and are constantly a few poor choices away from total collapse. All in all, the game is a great experience.Although I have not completed the game, just scratched the surface really (I've played three months in-game), I can say for certain that all of the difficulty of the original game is present. Every desicion is vital and it is imperative to really consider the best course of action at all times. If you don't, well, let's say there have been more than a few missions which resulted in complete annihilation of my squad, a terrible loss.The game is also much more faithful to the original than XCOM - ENEMY UNKNOWN, bringing back TU's, much larger squads, and a more complicated geoscape portion of the game. In many respects, though, it improves on the original. The OP Blaster bomb has been removed, the graphics look polished and attractive, and useful/relevant data is more easily accessed.However, I do not mean to say that the game is without faults. For new players to the series, there is hardly and tutorial to introduce them to the many facets of being an international super-secret alien defense force commander. This means the learning curve can be quite steep. Furthermore, the game has some frustrating line of sight issues. Sometimes, I will attempt to move my soldier to firing position, only to discover that the bush I was trying to shoot through might as well be a solid wall. Although over time I have been able to more successfully ascertain what I can and can't do, it has provided a great deal of frustration.All in all, the game is excellent, and in my oppinion more pleasurable to play than the original. (Although the punishing nature of the original adds a bit to the feel. Ironically by making it better it's worse?) Anyway, if you are a fan of strategy games or the original series then I would highly recommend you purchase this game immediately and begin fighting off the extraterrestrial invasion!

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Revist/remake of the old school Microprose UFO: Enemy Unknown game. Its very similar to the original with a lot of the content removed(multi-format release) from the latest XCOM game returning .This game has improved strategy in the global setting over Xcom, with you needing to way up more options like; do I build another base to incease radar & aircraft range or add labs & scientists to get better equipment. Time is not on your side, funding dissapears very quickly on hard settings, especially due to unmonitored alien activity.The visuals do a decent job as does the AI (on normal & above). The maps are reasonably varied, yet do repeat slightly more than i'd like. They're about the right size & unlike the original I havent found myself hunting the map for the last camping in a loft alien for 30 mins. Theres also a nice addition in the form of being able to airstrike downed UFO's rather than sending a team in. Overall I've throughly enjoyed this so far and am happy to recommend it, if you havent played the original this is well worth your money. Do bare in mind though that the game is very unforgiving, especailly on the more challenging modes.

								Most games find it difficult to provide a challenge, and make it feel fair, most end up having situations in which your character or characters are killed, and you feel cheated at tge way it happened, it normally feels like a cheap shot.Not in Xenonauts though.If a soldier is killed, you don´t feel like the game pulled a ♥♥♥♥ move, no, you know it was your fault, that you ♥♥♥♥ed up, and that you ♥♥♥♥ed up hard.Even then, losing soldiers is part of the game, the game clearly tells us that for all your preparations and tactics, you are still going to lose men and women to a much superior foe, and even if you start closing the gap, that it will keep happening, and happening, and there´s not much that you can do about it.But, that´s the alure of Xenonauts, a game that manages to strike a balance between challenge and fun.So, in short, this is a well recommended game.

								At the time of this review, the game was still in development and thus there were some glitches, bugs and balance issues.With that in mind, I still recommend this game as a somewhat successful x-com copy. Graphics arent the best, but I have to admit that old school graphics scare me more than fully detailed 3d and shiny aliens in newer games from bigger studios. the pace is quite slow and you have to ponder every move, slowly get your team into position for every corner (a thing about tactical turn based games) Difficulty wise, Xenonauts is a bit tough on beginners, however if you are reading this, that means you are after some depth and challenge in a game, anyway. For x-com veterans it should be a walk in the park (while getting killed many times by an unseen alien and reloading every now and then)Although targeted to a limited market, this game can only get better with time as developers work on it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
1, 2014
												Xenonauts is basically a modern remake of the original Xcom, and it retains most of its original features. -Uses TU(time units) which allows for a large diversity of actions to be taken during a turn, instead of the simplified scoot n shoot action system from Xcom:EU-Destructible Terrain: you can destroy light cover, such as haybales and low barricades, to larger things such as entire walls-Can have more than one base to operate from on the globe, and it can be placed in any exact location down to a pixel-Base building: a 6 by 6 grid that can be outfitted with a variety of structures to win the war-Base assault and defense: You can assault alien strongholds on earth and vice versa-Medium size combat teams: You get to start off with 8 units, and you can increase that amount to 10 later on.-No class restricting roles: You can equip any soldier with any item, and designate their roles as you deem fit. -Soldier Inventory system: though slightly streamlined, (no more leg or shoulder slots, just hands, belt, and backpack.) you   can equip soldiers with as much as they can carry weight/space wise. For those uninitiated into the wonder of the Xcom universe, the game basically plays as a world defense simulator. The earth gets attacked by aliens, and all of the worlds super powers are left bent over a table with their pants down. You, and your organization, the Xenonauts, are effectively the last defense we have left. You start out by placing a base on the globe, and then monitor alien activity around you via radar dishes. While things are dark, you can research alien artifacts and technology,  build new military toys, and invest in both your base and its employees. Once a Ufo is spotted, you can choose to launch a fighter or interceptor to its location to try and shoot it down. If you succeed, you'll most likely be given the option to send a mop up crew to kill off any survivors and acquire whatever the ship had aboard it. Alternatively, you can also send in an airstrike in to obliterate the crash site, netting you a small amount of cast from the pieces left. Once a crew of soldiers arrives at a crashsite or other battlefield, the game plays out in a turn based fashion. You move your soldiers around a battlefield, using various cover, weapons, and equipment to out position and destroy your foe. Whether that be by blowing a hole in the side of a building and running inside to flank an enemy, tossing a flash bang or smoke grenade to disorient and charge the enemy head on, or laying down supressive fire while a sniper gets into position and guns down an enemy. The choice is up to you. While Xenonauts does however, have its own share of faults, (Playing the same levels over and over in combat missions, predictable enemies inside downed ufos, graphics ocassionally bugging out, etc.) they are few and far between, and the game can be modded to the point where most of these things are not an issue. If you liked the original Xcom, I can almost assure you that you will love this game, and if you've never played one before, you should give it a shot.

content:
7, 2014
												If you loved the original X-Com, you will like this game a lot.This game can be rather unforgiving if you're not well versed in the old games. The X-Com reboot is but a pale shadow of what this game is. (That's not to say X-Com wasn't fun. It totally was).Xenonauts will test your patience in the battlefield as well as your tactical senses. If you're impatient and charge in, you'll be replacing soldiers more often than not. If you decide to make a beeline to the UFO, you could get blindsided by aliens you didn't see.Outside of the actual battlefield and into the Global Map, there are a fair few choices as well. Research is all important so that you begin to level the playing field between you an the aliens. You will also need to decide whether or not to expand quickly or build up your current base and its forces. There are bonuses but also negative points to this. A new base means more coverage, happier nations, more UFOs to tag, etc, but then you have to juggle this with the costs involved with running a new base. Because of the depth this game offers, this game is a welcome sight to strategy veterans.

9, 2015
												This started out hard, but fun. And then psionics happened to it. For a supposedly tactical game, half your success on missions comes down to "not failing your save against psionic enemies with unlimited range and no line of sight required". You don't get psionics to throw back at them, you don't get any counters to it, and you have no idea where the attacks are coming from. Usually it's some enemy on the far end of the map, so you can't even try and rush them to remove the threat.It's not a challenge, it's just random rolls that occasionally mean half your team freezes and you waste a round. This game would have been better off without it, or limiting psionics to line of sight so you can do crazy OP tactics like "scouting" and "planning". Get XCom-Enemy Within, it uses actual game difficulty rather than arbitrarily zapping you.

												This is one of the best turn based strategy games I have ever played. It is very well made; I have seen no glitchs or bugs, and the controls make miss-clicks a rare occurence. The difficulty scale is great as well. At the lower levels, it is more forgiving for new players yet still really fun. At the higher difficulties, it requires a high level of both stategic and tactical knowledge to survive, providing a very satisfiying challenge that I have not seen since Civ V.The only problems I have with the game is that it does not tell how long some things may take to do, like researching tech and hiring new personel. This is a minor issue however, because after several playthroughs you have a general idea of how long these things may take to do.Overall, Xenonauts is a great strategy game (9 of 10) and is well worth playing.

												I am not going to review the mechanics of this game. There are far better game reviews out there for this. Instead this couple of paragraphs are mostly for those of you that are on the fence about purchasing this game. I purchased this game right before it came out of beta but I would have happly bought it even at its full price. The original X-Com: UFO Defense (1994 MicroProse) was a truly remarkable game and but for the graphics stands up well to games released today. Xenonauts recreates the original game (with a few extra suprises) very well. The developers have updated the graphics and improved the AI. The game is challanging even on the average setting. I have yet to try the higher settings. If you have never played the original X-Com, this game is a must. If you have played X-Com, you owe it to yourself to get this game. It will bring back memories of sitting in front of your computer for hours on end trying to destroy the alien base and save the world.So, if you are on the fence, don't be. Click the buy button. If you enjoy turn based squad action, you are going to love this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
4, 2014
												This game is a quality revitalization of the original X-COM.  It not only met the high standards set by the 90s classic but also exceeded the benchmark in many ways.  - This is a global war fought by many nations that join in the fight.  Militaries around the world as well as farmers with shotguns will aid the multi-national force in its fight against the alien invasion.  Occassionally they bring down alien crafts (at terrible losses),   Allied units are represented as cops on the street, farmers blasting aliens on the other side of the farm as your troops hunt aliens around haystacks, or national militaries desperately defending the city during terror missions  - Interception missions are extremely fun - take personal control of your interceptors to bait and flank enemy crafts once your squadron catches up to an enemy flight (it could be a battleshield escorted by two fighters, or just a lone scout) - this minigame is many times more fun than X-COM's interception mission.  - Your soldiers earn medals for performing extraordinary tasks - the medals in turn boost their stats- Many weapons to choose from - riot shields (wield one with a pistol), shotguns, rifles, sniper rifles, RPGs, HMGs, researched alien technologies, even a TANK that will eventually look like a real tank (upon further research).  Who doesn't want to use a tank to blow away aliens?  In X-COM games, the tank is always a tiny robo-craft that look gimpy... here we have a real tank!  - Addressed many short-comings in the original X-COM game.  You can now fly the troop transport to multiple crash sites, direct interceptors to target one group of enemy after another (assuming enough ammo and fuel left).  - It is a challenging but highly rewarding game.  It is fair (none of that enemy "spawning" behavior in X-COM Enemy Unknown), but it is tough.  I would rather have a tough game that is fair than an easy game with funky game logics. I am an avid X-COM player: 5 playthroughs in the original X-COM, 1 playthrough of TFTD (ok that was torture), 1 playthrough for Apocalypse, 1 playthrough in X-COM EU.  I am proud to say that Xenonaut has won me over as the quality spiritual successor that I have always been looking for.

content:
, 2014
												A great recreation of the original X-Com, with some much appreciated improvements to air combat and simplification of the base management UI and so forth. Some drawbacks as expected - the shiny new tilesets mean you can't breach a UFO like you can all the other buildings - and money can be hard to come by if you are not dominating the air battle (which in turn means you can't produce the planes you need to dominate the air battle....). However I have sunk about 13 hours into this over the weekend and still keep wanting to see one more mission, wipe out one more alien base, save Budapest from the alien terror attacks....Big recommendation from me!

content:

												I am an O.G.(original gamer). I started out on a commidor 64 back in the mid 80's. With that said I had x-com from the start. It was then, and still now in my memory as an amazing game that was fun, challaging, scary, and more. I loved everything about it at the time. I could go on and on but to tie this together I wish to say Xenonauts has eceeded my expectation in every way. Well done! I have been burnt out for years on games made for money, not games made by gamers who want to build a really great game. Xenonauts has restored that long lost passion I once felt while emersed into a great game. I hope you will try this game, if you do then get in a quiet dark place, kick back and dive in, you might just find your new favorite game.

												Easy to like, but hard to love. content:
ry 8, 2016
												Look at the title of the game, It's not XCOM, get that through your head. It has very similar mechanics, and fictional setting, but is not XCOM, so if you are a bored XCOM fan who beat all of the new installments; this may not be a good purchase for you. Secondly, if you choose to continue and buy the game, know that it is beyond realisticly hard, in which you need to keep up with the fast pace of the game or you will fail and basically need to make a new game. Two, understand you are fighting a space faring race, fighting as a non-space faring race and are at a critical disadvantage. What am I trying to say? This game is hard, you need to learn fast, make good decisions, have a plan, always save the game, and keep your airfleet either in strong numbers or advanced. Welcome to Xenonauts.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
, 2016
												To give you an idea of what this game is like, I wrote this:You are the last man in your squad, Reapers have zombified every human in the city and to your dismay one of them pursuing you. You are too busy looking behind you to realize you have been backed into an alley,  you look behind you once again to see your adversary facing you, Snappinng It's massive mouth with hundreds of incredibly sharp teeth. You can feel its hot breath against your skin, you think it is the end, and put your rifle's muzzle against your neck. But your luck changes, and you realize the reaper has exhausted their time unit supply. You lower the gun and point it at the reaper, "95% it will hit." you think to yourself. You point your rifle at the reaper's head, and close your eyes. "A 95% chance I will live." You smile and pull the trigger. You hear the gun fire and feel the recoil of the bullet leaving the chamber, you open your eyes and hope to see a headless reaper corpse in front of you. Unfortunate as it is, you missed the shot and the reaper in front of you still has a head and still wants to kill you and use your body as a vessel for its parasitic spawn.10/10 would lose "Pvt. John Mctiggles" exactly like that again.

												This game is wonderful in all the ways that the classic xcom is. It is improved in everyway, the graphics are great. the game mechanics are wonderful and lots of micro managment style features that are a game in and of themselves. Aaaand then there is the BS. Like xcom you will miss impossible easy shots. drop grenades  and have collateral damage. This game magnifys thats by five times and thats being conservative. I am a veteran of the xcom franshise and have played hundreds of hours of both of these games. I am playing on easy (ironman mode) but still easy and I cannot even play the game because it feels like i am playing against a eight year old with god powers. "nah you miss and hit a civilian, ohh is your friend throwing a grenade at me woops you dropped it and exploded half your squad" ok now you panic and your friend goes bonkers and shoot into the rest of your squad. ok now my turn".   I do love this game but it is not for the faint of heart and i wish they would just make it fair Ps. the doors on the ship always auto close at the end of the aliens turns. so you end up getting shot and to return fire you have to blast through doors. Makes it so much harder

content:
5, 2014
												XCOM:UFO Defense was released the year I graduated. Let me clarify that I do not remember the release date because it is the same as my graduation. I remember my graduation date because of the release date. I first saw this played on a 486DX and then had to hack and upgrade my Tandy 1000EX to be able to run it. I spent $700 in 1993 money to upgrade my RAM to a whopping 768kb. In the end I upgraded machines to play this, Mechwarrior and AOE.I have also played numerous attempts at sequels, upgrades and fan made remakes. There is NOTHING that come even close to this one. This game is solid, true to it's roots and adds, answers all the things you wanted in the original without ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the things that made it unique. True the last update wiped the scalable destruction but it is a small price to pay. I would spend twice the price for this.
